name: 英國文學：中古時期至十八世紀（二）
goals: To improve students’ knowledge of British culture and written and spoken English through a thematically-related sample of British literature
syllabus:
**Survey of English Literature: From the Middle Ages to the Eighteenth Century**

Dr. Aaron Deveson (aaron.c.deveson@gmail.com)

Text: The Norton Anthology of English Literature (Tenth Edition)

The purpose of this two-semester course is to introduce students to a range of writing in English from the medieval period up to the eighteenth century. This semester we shall be studying literature **from the early seventeenth century up to the end of the eighteenth century**. The ideas or themes we shall be considering include ambiguity, ambivalence, consolation, resistance, interiority, irony, escapism, sex, failure, intimacy, liberty, and slavery.

Historical context is provided in the seminars, but students will need to be doing their own background reading if they are to be successful in their work. Students are advised to bring English-Chinese dictionaries to class and to keep a notebook in which to add new vocabulary.

**Grading Policy:**

**Midterm: 40%**

Part I   Practical criticism (response to extracts)

Part II  Medium-length essays

**Presentation/Contribution: 20%**       

Presentations must include images and be no longer than 4 mins each (topics TBA)

**Final: 40%**

        Essay (topics TBA)

**SCHEDULE:**

WEEK 1

**The Caroline Court/ The English Revolution/Civil War**

Robert Herrick: “To the Virgins, to Make Much of Time”

WEEK 2 (first presentations))

**Leaving time with the Cavalier poets**

Richard Lovelace: “The Grasshopper”

WEEKS 3 AND 4

**Poetry of ambivalence**

Andrew Marvell: “The Garden,” and other poems

WEEKS 5 and 6

**Active vision**

John Milton: Sonnets (“To the Lord General Cromwell \[…\]”, “When I Consider \[…\]”, “Methought I Saw \[…\]”) 

WEEK 7 and 8

Milton: _Paradise Lost_ (selections)

WEEK 9

**MIDTERM**

WEEK 10

**Imperfect humans**

John Dryden, John Wilmot, Second Earl of Rochester, and Aphra Behn

WEEKS 11 and 12

Jonathan Swift

WEEKS 13 and 14

Alexander Pope and Lady Mary Wortley Montagu

WEEK 15

**Liberty and social death**

Writings by Mary Astell, Edmund Burke, Samuel Johnson, Olaudah Equiano, and others included in “Liberty” section of Norton  

William Cowper: “The Negro’s Complaint” (photocopy)

WEEK 16

**FINAL**

WEEKS 17 AND 18

**Self-supported study**
